text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name VAVRA CHARLES
Present Address 213 Clarence Ave S, Saskatoon
Pioneer Address Battleford, Scott when Railroad was built
Year you came to Saskatchewan May 1926

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Only my own.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Every other day in winter, or when the weather permitted.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Any day weather permitting.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Visiting was done without invitation as we could not depend on the weather.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Mostly in afternoons and evenings according to weather.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? It was only natural to stay for dinner when visiting, visitors were always welcome.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? There was no other refreshments unless there was very limited little money and only 3 or 4 trips to town a year.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Women fell seldom left house with children.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Not in early days.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

When country settled little more than 3 years later had one or two bands at half breed store in winter in what they called at that time 60 mile Band, 60 miles from Battleford.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. Parties just played whist & talked - not enough people for Parties.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. From 1908 on moved to North Plenty of Dance, then 4 or 5 women girls at the dance and from 20 to 30 times lot of men dancing together.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

1. In the first five years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting?

2. How often did you visit neighbors? (every day, every week, rarely)

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Any day weather permitting.

4. Have you often invited others to visit? If so, what was the purpose of the invitation?

5. Did the weather affect your decision to visit?

6. Did you ever have teas when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, drives, or dances in homes? Describe.

8. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as visiting by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? No
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

It took two years before there were any schools. All country schools were used for dances and social activities. Not a town school we had town hall.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Not very much the winters were cold and stormy school house too small to hold many times, and in summer everybody was working, store away from home.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1909 or 1910 in Town Scott.

What material was it made of? Brick. How large was it? Good size hall fire hall offices & living quarters for teachers, club, jail.

Who built it? The community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Town Built Hall.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village to start with Town Hall.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) We went in town to take in all social gatherings. I was Harness Maker then. Farmers had their gatherings in school house to town hall for picture show and larger gatherings.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? In country school house yes.

How were babies and small children provided for? Little ones went to sleep upstairs on berths as a rule older women took care of children.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Packed into barns in town there were liveries Barns.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Mostly all what?

Has there card playing for a prize? Very seldom.

What dances were popular? Waltz, Polka, two step & quadrilles.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Not many were opposed to dancing if they did not like it they went to their own gatherings. We had no trouble.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some would not play but very fond of card playing.
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, etc.) Give dates.

8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, etc.) Give dates.

If you have not answered all questions, please answer them now.

Did you ever have a country dance? If so, when?

Describe the dance hall or hall used.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district?

Describe how the school building was used for social gatherings.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some would not play but would prefer card playing.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Lots of them

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Telling stories was very common and interesting and most people knew lots of them.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Modern Woodmen of America and Independent Order of Foresters

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

This was organized around 1910-1911. Social gatherings for men and protection for family in case of accident.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Don't remember the year. Mostly to get better deal in selling grain elevators covered by first what they liked.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Don't remember but expect it was over 50%.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Monthly in winter

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Mostly to build our own grain elevators and partly reason of organizing Wheat Pool.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not in early days

When was it organized? Don't remember

Approximately how many women belonged to it? Quite few in later years

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

12. Was the obituary known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were.

13. Describe any incidents connected with them, such as gatherings, parties, etc., that you remember.

14. Describe any other details of meetings, parties, etc., that you remember.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. How many women belonged to this organization? How often did it meet?

18. What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

19. How many women belonged to its auxiliary? How often did it meet?

20. Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

There were not many organization activities before 1914. Winters were cold and stormy summers were short. All were freezing new land and putting up buildings as the flames permitted. Many sod houses roofs were leaking, some had no floors.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? mostly straight collections

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? Hall & School Houses if any. Houses were too small.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? Don't remember

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, tall, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Fly kites, marbles and some Ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Skipping rope & Play House & hide and seek
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1924, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, who was its leader, what its chief purpose was, whether it was a religious or secular organization, whether it included people only in one relatively small area, or included within a school district, or was carried throughout the town or even the county.

There were not many organizations before 1924. Winters were cold and snowy, summers were very hot. Short air was needed and putting up buildings as well as building towers for us floors.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? Give dates if possible.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

That games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Skating in Town & Hockey*

   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Card games and checkers*

   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *Parents seldom played with children*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Only in Winter everyone was too busy in summer to play.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Don't remember*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
   *Give year and month if possible.*  
   *Not before 1915*

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *Picnics in later years on Experimental Farm*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *After and Knowes*

   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Speakers and going true the plots & grain and gardens.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *All were eating in small groups on the grass.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Sandwiches & Cake*  
   *Drink coffee or tea supplied by Epp Farm.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *Started in the Morning finished by supper time all had to go home to do chores. Some came back later for the Dance*
22. What toys, games were played outside? For each board, skating, etc.? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

What games were played indoors in winter—card games such as "Happy Families," "whist," or others? 

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

Explain, truly or write everyone went too busy in summer to play.

23. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

24. Picnics and games.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saugatuck?

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If so, when?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic? You attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Remember one speech by Minister of Education started when he received his education. He thought he knew it all then, and soon found out how little he knew.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

All picnics or larger gatherings were held after 1914 when country was more settled people began to organize in different groups.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

In early days everybody mixed there were no introductions needed since about 1920 different classes formed and people separated more according to class they belong to.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Old people were too tired to take in many sports. Young people played baseball, had races, young men did quite a bit of skating, hockey, softball, basketball, chicken wire football, and some entente.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Mostly Hockey and Baseball

What year? about 1912 How long did it continue? for several years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Summer baseball and horse racing were very popular.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

About 1912 used for hockey and skating, curling rink was added later.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Indoor rink was only curling rink 2 sheets.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any differences in picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the inclusion of religious services, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc., about any differences in manners attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your town? How many teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1911, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

and how racing was very popular
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? About 1912 or 1913. Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? In time it did.

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Business men of the town.

When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st.) July 1st or July 4th.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. We had some real good hockey players. 3 were outstanding but they never played with any other teams.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

We had nothing to read to select of I was interested in old History but seldom could get any Books.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? None.

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Very little if any.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Some time.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? None.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. No.

48. Was there a school library? No. When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Children had mostly only Primary Books.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? about 1925

41. Was there any from your community who have become members of well-known teams or clubs? Give names and dates.

42. Are there any from your community who have been responsible for starting the first sports day? (Sept. 1st or July 1st)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

44. What kind of books and how many?

45. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

46. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?  
When was it started?  
Who started it?  
Is it still in existence?  
If not, when was it discontinued, and why?  

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?  
St. Scott weekly news paper and mostly Free Press. Also received papers from U.S.A.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.  
Stopped U.S.A. papers by did not favor settlement as country of opportunity.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?  
Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.  
Yes there were no money for Books and if there were they were hard to get in suburb town Crosby stories were most plentiful.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the West? (Check each weekly, semi-weekly, monthly, daily, and currently.)

Free Press. All were delivered by mail from U.S.A.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

For those who want plenty full in such all known Groovy stories will want plenty full
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Cornet and never played it with orchestra.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Harmonica and violin.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

Organ & Piano at Saskatoon. Bought corn Organ for $300 in 1920. Heideman Piano about 1930. Total value of organ and piano $750 to $800.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. Very little.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. Not in early days, later Brotherlaw had his own orchestra and three of his children played in the district.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Plow in the Rockies

in the community? Old time music brought from USA and some from Old Country (Czechoslovakia).

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. Not in early days in Saskatchewan.

Popular in Old Country in my boyhood days.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started?

Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

In early days people were too few and too far apart to form even an orchestra.
Musical Entertainment

56. What musical instrument did you bring with you when you came to the United States?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the United States? (List them.)

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home life in early years? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke or something? Or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances. No

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? Modern music is not as popular as old time music used to be. Rock is gone out of it with modern music.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Yes

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. Yes

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned. Reading history

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? No

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary). There was very little social life in early days. Homesteaders were busy breaking up land, putting rocks and putting up buildings (mostly sod) badly needed. Businesses were in towns kept open all hours of day and night.
10.

64. Has anyone from your community been well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearance.

65. Is music an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, describe them.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you began, what interested you in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

READING HISTORY

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading habits of pioneer days not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)

Little town life in early days. People worked very hard. Putting up buildings quickly and boldly needed. Businesses were kept open all hours of day and night.
Oxford
